episode_summary: This episode covers a range of quirky and fascinating facts, including the unusual method of counting pandas through their excrement, a dedicated Wikipedia editor's mission to correct a common grammatical error, the world's largest saw used in Kazakhstan, and the history of race walking with its peculiar rules.

facts.fact: Until the mid-2000s, the best method for finding out how many pandas were alive was to sift through their poo.

Since 2007, the Wikipedia editor Brian Henderson has made more than 50,000 edits and all of them are exactly the same: tracking down articles using the words 'comprised of' and changing them to 'consists of'.
The world's largest saw is used to cut through mountains in Kazakhstan.
In the early days of race walking or speed walking, the competitors were allowed to jog as necessary to relieve cramp.
